content: The "John F. Kennedy Centennial Commission Act" establishes a commission to honor John F. Kennedy on the 100th anniversary of his birth. The Commission will plan and carry out activities, provide advice to government agencies and civic groups, and develop activities for the Federal Government to honor Kennedy. The "John F. Kennedy Centennial Commission Act" establishes a commission to honor John F. Kennedy on the occasion of the 100th anniversary of his birth. The Commission will be composed of 11 members, including the Secretary of the Interior, members appointed by the President, House of Representatives, and Senate, as well as the Archivist of the United States as an ex officio member. The Archivist of the United States serves on the Commission in an ex officio capacity to provide advice. Each member is appointed for the life of the Commission, with vacancies filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Members do not receive compensation but are reimbursed for travel expenses. The Commission appoints an executive director and necessary staff to perform duties. The director and employees may be appointed without regard to certain civil service laws. The chairperson is elected by a majority vote of the members. A majority of members constitute a quorum for business, with two or more members able to hold hearings. The Commission may appoint an executive director and staff without following certain civil service laws. The Secretary of the Interior or the Archivist of the United States can detail employees to assist the Commission. The Commission can also hire temporary services as needed. The Commission has the power to hold hearings, receive evidence, use the United States mails, and obtain official data from other government departments. They can also accept voluntary and uncompensated services as needed. The Commission has the authority to request information from government departments, accept gifts and donations, utilize available space provided by the Administrator of General Services, and enter into contracts to fulfill its duties. Additionally, the Commission is required to submit annual reports to the President. The Commission is required to submit annual reports on revenue and expenditures, including gifts over $250. Interim reports may also be submitted, and a final report with activities, funds, and recommendations is due by August 31, 2017. The Commission may terminate at its discretion. The Commission may terminate after submitting its final report by September 30, 2017. The Inspector General of the Department of the Interior can conduct audits, share results publicly, and report to specific committees. No Federal funds can be used for this Act.
